abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory overall. The key lessons learned are: 1) No
            project is likely to be implemented in accordance with plans
            unless there is some government's ownership of the
            project. 2) In order to be implemented successfully a
            pre-investment project requires a minimum of organization
            and staffing on the Borrower side, and preferably the
            availability of an administrative and accounting manual to
            facilitate procurement, contract administration, and
            disbursement. 3) Bank supervision of a pre-investment
            project represents a significant amount of work for
            procurement, contract administration, and disbursement. 4)
            Government counterpart contribution should be in cash,
            rather than in kind, and based on a realistic assessment of
            the Government willingness and ability to pay for studies
            and similar activities. 5) The design of the project should
            include a realistic assessment of demand for financing for
            studies, preferably with the identification of studies and
            training to be financed during the first year of project implementation.

docna.cdata!:
Togo - Preinvestment Project : Credit 2018 -
            Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Togo - Preinvestment Project :
            Credit 2018 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has both immediate and
            long-term objectives. Firstly, to relieve the immediate
            constraints on investments caused by the present lack of
            properly prepared projects; and, secondly, over the project
            period, to create the institutional capacity for identifying
            investment proposals and processing these through
            feasibility studies, obtaining financing and establishing
            final project execution plans. The project will achieve
            these objectives through the following components: (i) an
            investment preparation component in the form of feasibility
            studies and detailed execution plans of projects included in
            the Government's triennial Public Investment Program;
            and (ii) a sectoral priorities component in the form of
            studies and training to supplement present knowledge of
            sectoral investment priorities. The studies are to be
            carried out under, or such training to be provided to, the
            planning units of the relevent technical ministries.
